The problem with online fiction is that you can‚Äôt tap into the native features of the medium, namely, hyperlinks.

In fiction, the author creates a dreamscape for the reader to inhabit. Even the smallest interruption to the narrative flows dismantles the fragile dream.

Hyperlinks are a hard break.

I was thinking about this in relation to this article by  on hyperlinks as a new type of grammar. But it‚Äôs a type of grammar uniquely suited to nonfiction and unsuited to fiction.

https://www.ribbonfarm.com/2009/07/01/the-rhetoric-of-the-hyperlink/

I think this is why nonfiction has been in a long internet-fueled Renaissance (first with blogs, now with newsletters). 

Non-fiction has a lot to gain by hyperlinking, and hyperlinking is arguably the engine driving its success. Nonfiction is an internet-native medium.

But fiction writing feels eclipsed.

I think this explains, too, why eBooks haven‚Äôt caught on as much as early proponents predicted. All the new features that eBooks can bring to the reading experience are just more ways to break the dreamworld.

https://countercraft.substack.com/p/maybe-the-book-doesnt-need-to-disrupted

Nobody wants to watch a video in the middle of reading a story. It shatters the flow.

It‚Äôs like putting a commercial in the middle of a movie (a travesty).

But it‚Äôs worse than that because it takes sustained effort on the reader‚Äôs part to conjure the fictive world, unlike in visual narratives (which are a hot medium, in the McLuhan sense) where content-switching is so fast as to be almost immediate.

Content switching of that sort is impossible in written fiction. Or maybe just really hard? Perhaps someone will unlock new internet-native fictive features. 

But I doubt it.

I think the concept of retirement (like so many things) has become distorted.

There‚Äôs the buy a house in Florida and waste away in Margaritaville sense of retirement, and that deserves its reproach.

But there‚Äôs also a Michel de Montaigne retirement, where you step back into a more reflective mode.

The type of work you do should change as you move into different life stages.

We miss this subtlety because the word ‚Äúwork‚Äù is too flabby and imprecise.

How can there not be confusion when you can work to run a company, work on a novel, and work on your golf swing.

I‚Äôll say it: losing the active badge hurt.

It felt like a rejection. Like I was rejected from a core piece of this community.

My rational brain says: who cares? It's just a popularity contest. It doesn't mean anything.

But it's actually more than that. The badge is like a passport to the Farcaster ecosystem.

A surprising number of things are gatekept by the active badge. 

The Farcaster OG NFT only went to those that had it. I was lucky enough to qualify then, but now that I‚Äôve lost it, a nasty feeling seeps in: what will I miss out on now? The FOMO is real, and it is acute.

There are other mints and things that require the active badge. It's like suddenly losing your passport‚Äîwhere you could once travel freely is blocked.

But, I also accept that these are my feelings. And they aren't really about the active badge at all.

This experience (and similar ones this week) have forced me to look at an ugly part of myself I do not like to see.

Deep down, I fear rejection‚Äîmaybe more than anything else. Driven by that fear, I have a tendency to reject others before they can reject me.

I understand that I did that here. I kept this place at arm‚Äôs length. If I hadn‚Äôt, if I had been more active, more engaged I would probably have more followers. It would be a moot point.

But Farcaster remains curiously peripheral to me, and this loss increases that feeling of distance.

Here I stand at the edge of the sea. I have choices: I can dive in, increase my activity, get it back. Or I can drift away quietly (like I usually do).

Again, though, this feels like rationalization. My ego is bruised and I reach out for any sort of justification for it.

I don‚Äôt expect or want anything to change. Why should it? 

But I wanted to write this so if anyone else was grappling with these feelings, they might feel a little less alone.

I don't think taste is objective, but it isn't entirely subjective, either. It's intersubjective. A bit of both.

When someone says "you have good taste" what they mean is that your subjective aesthetics align with my own.

Tastemakers are those whose refined aesthetic sense is strong enough they can get others to align in their direction.

The big problem is the same as it is in Web2: discovery. 

Web2 "solved" this via algorithmic content delivery, which resulted in all the problems you list in part II. Creators learned how to influence the algorithm, but were influenced in turn. And the platforms benefitted the most.

In the mean time, algorithms eliminated the human curatorial element.

Everyone wants to eliminate the gatekeeper. Web3 doubles down on this and calls it "permissionless."

But gatekeeper is the wrong framing. It turns out you need tastemakers for good discovery.

What seems to have disappeared in the writing space is the role of the critic. Someone who decides what's worth reading and what isn't.

But there were good reasons to dismantle that apparatus. Postmodern critique rightfully questioned "the canon" as exclusionary and complicit in upholding power structures.

That combined with technology which allows anyone to publish anything at any time, and the result is obvious: a relentless firehose of content. 

I think the answer is probably a balance: the creator-critic, centered around groups or scenes. They both contribute to the scene and decide what is and isn't "in."
